review: We wanted internet TV (mainly Netflix) on a TV in our bedroom but didn't want to run wires or buy a wireless bridge just for that TV.  I stumbled on this little guy almost by accident and thought I'd give it a try...after all, it was only $35.  It's awesome!  I simply plugged it in, set it up on my existing wireless network, then I can watch netflix on this TV by initiating (and controlling) the program from my iPad, laptop, or even my iPhone.  Once the program is playing, it streams over your network, not through your device, so you can turn off your laptop or ipad and just watch the movie.
author: Justin Harmon

author: Dr. J. A. Metcalf

review: This is one of those little gadgets that are super easy to setup, does just one thing and does it well. And on top of it, it's cheap.The only problem is that the number of applications supporting the still-in-beta Cast SDK is VERY lacking (blame Google!), you have YouTube, you have Netflix, Hulu, Google Play, and that's it. And you should consider that the only "universal" service among those is YouTube. All the others have their own restrictions in terms of geographic availability.Also, the platform is restricted to Android, iOS and the Chrome browser (with some issues).As my HDTV doesn't support YouTube nor Netflix natively, and I already owned a couple of Android devices, the Chromecast turned to be the best alternative, considering size, price and features.The "Cast Tab" in the Chrome browser feels extremely "beta" (if not "alpha") quality, and you really need a powerful PC or laptop and a very good wifi network if you want to make anything mildly useful with it.So, if considering its many restrictions it fits your bill, then it's almost perfect. If not, you'll be wasting your money.
author: Mariano Draghi

review: I saw this on a tech website and decided to give it a go since it was 35 bucks and I was tired of hooking my laptop up to my TV via HDMI when I wanted to watch a movie on a bigger screen.  I've got to say that 35 dollars was quite well spent.  It works perfectly with the Amazon prime movies when I cast it from Chrome on my laptop, and Youtube from my Galaxy S3 casts effortlessly. I love how you can queue the TV on the phone, and how easy it is for other smartphones to use the device as well (my family essentially has three remotes!) I've used Google Music from my phone a couple times, and that worked great, but definitely not as useful as the other two ways I mainly use it for.  I know Google is working on other apps for the casting to work, but for me, this was already worth the money for the convenience it provided.
author: Lucas Lin
